Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for the Afton Chemical Facility in Sauget, Illinois



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances (68.155(b))



The Afton Chemical Facility, located in Sauget, Illinois, (the "Facility") operates a variety of processes to produce lubricant additive packages that help meet or exceed a wide range of industry and government performance standards.  The most prominent of these include reducing exhaust emissions, improving fuel economy, prolonging oil-drain intervals, and extending equipment life.  The Facility has one regulated flammable substance (2-methylpropene, commonly referred to as isobutylene) and two regulated toxic substances (chlorine and carbon disulfide).  



Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies (68.155(a))



The Facility has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  The Facility invests in accident prevention, including, but not limited to, the Facility's training of its personnel and the Facility's commitment and consideration of safety in every phase of its operations- from the design to the installation, operation, and maintenance of its processes. The Facility has a Spill Prevention, Containment, and Countermeasure (SPCC) policy which addresses prevention of foreseeable releases of regulated substances as well as the circumstances that if an accidental release occurs, how its personnel will respond to, control and contain that release.    



Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps (68.155(c)) 



(A)    Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:



(i)    Toxic Substance Scenarios:



The worst-case scenario for toxic release is a catastrophic failure of a 90-ton chlorine railcar, resulting in a release of 179,000 lbs. of chlorine gas over a 10-minute period.  Although we have numerous controls to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for administrative controls or passive mitigation measures is taken into accou

nt in evaluating this scenario.  Because the plant is located in a populated area, the toxic cloud formed by such an event would reach off-site public receptors. 



An alternative scenario for chlorine is a failure of the 2-in. diameter liquid charge line between the railcar and the vaporizer.  If this scenario were to occur, automatic sensors would detect chlorine and shut off flow from the railcar immediately, releasing only the contents of the line (approximately 38 lbs. of chlorine) to the atmosphere.  The toxic cloud formed by such an event would reach public receptors immediately adjacent to the facility boundary. 



An alternative scenario for carbon disulfide is a failure of a 2-in. diameter liquid charge line from a storage tank to a reactor.  If this scenario were to occur, our operators would shut off the flow from the tank within a few minutes.   With the assumption that it requires approximately 1 hour to stop the spill, the results from our analysis should be larger than would actually be the case if this event were to occur.  The toxic cloud formed by such an event would reach nearby public receptors.



(ii)    Flammable Substance Scenarios:



The worst-case scenario for flammable release is a vapor cloud explosion involving a full railcar inventory of isobutylene.  The maximum railcar inventory of 160,000 lbs. is assumed to be released to the atmosphere, to completely vaporize, and to ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Although we have numerous controls to prevent such releases and to manage their consequences, no credit for passive mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating this scenario. The overpressure generated by the explosion would reach nearby off-site public receptors.  



An alternative scenario for isobutylene is a rupture of an unloading hose from a railcar containing isobutylene.  If this scenario were to occur, our operators would shut off the flow from the railcar within a few minutes.  For this scenario, ho

wever, we chose to assume that it takes 15 minutes to stop the release, so that the results from our analysis should be larger than would actually be the case if this event were to occur.  The isobutylene spilled during this 15-minute period is assumed to ignite, resulting in a pool fire.  The excessive thermal radiation generated by the pool fire would reach public receptors immediately adjacent to the facility boundary.



(B)    General Accidental Release Prevention Program Steps



The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Facility.  Because processes at the plant that are regulated by the EPA risk management program (RMP) rule are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) rule, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements that are part of the RMP prevention program and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.



(1)    Employee Participation



The Facility encourages employees to participate in all facets of PSM and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team.  Employees have access to all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program.



(2)    Process Safety Information



The Facility maintains a number of technical documents used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within the facility are responsible for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.



Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sh

eets (SDSs).  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  The Facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in the operating procedures for each process, and ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g. automated shutdown systems).  



The Facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.



(3)    Process Hazard Analysis



The Facility has a comprehensive program to ensure that hazards associated with the each covered process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.



The Facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis (PHA) results at least once every 5 years until a process is no longer operating. Between formal PHA reviews, the Facility conducts "Potential Problem Analyses" (PPAs) when changes to the process warrant such an evaluation. This mechanism also ensures that the process controls and/or process hazards do not deviate significantly from the original design safety features.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  



(4)    Operating Procedures



T

he Facility maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, including, but not limited to, (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These written procedures are used for both reference and training materials.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  



In addition, the operating procedures at the Facility provide guidance on how to respond in the event of an exceedence for process or equipment specific parameters.  This information is readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks.



(5)    Employee Training



The Facility has implemented a comprehensive training program for any employees involved in operating a process.  After successfully completing initial training in the operations of the facility, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate adequate knowledge to perform the duties in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. 

 

All operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  Each employee's training is documented, including the verification that the employee understood the training.



(6)    Contractors



The Facility uses contractors to supplement its work force.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the Facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety

rules, and (6) inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.    Plant personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.



(7)    Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)



The Facility conducts a PSSR for any facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



(8)    Safety Reviews of Mechanical Integrity and Equipment



The Facility has well-established practices and procedures to maintain major process equipment and emergency response systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.



Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the process, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner.  Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equi

pment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels), and if a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service  or a management of change (MOC) team will review the use of the equipment.



Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The Facility incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.



(9)    Safe Work Practices



The Facility has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety, including (1) personnel entry control, (2) a lockout/tagout and energy isolation procedure, (3) a procedure to safely remove hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a permit and procedure to control spark-producing activities (i.e., hot work), and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure safe entry into a confined space. 



(10)     Management of Change



The Facility has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that changes to the process that are not considered "replacement in kind" are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected process information and operating and maintenance procedures are updated accordingly, and training is provided, as needed.



Additionally, the Facility has incorporated a formal review system for organizational and personnel changes.  This review focuses on the supervisory and support staff roles that provide management or technical support to the processes to ensure process safety and process support responsibilities are continuous throughout the change.



(11)     Incident Investigation



The Facility promptly investigates all incidents that result in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire, explosion, or toxic gas release that caused major property damage, environmental

loss, or personal injury.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations.  



(12)    Compliance Audits



To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Facility periodically conducts an audit of the procedures and practices required by this accident prevention program.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  



(13)     Chemical-specific Prevention Steps



The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all EPA RMP-covered processes at the plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by (1) equipment failures and (2) human errors.



In addition to the accident prevention program activities, the Afton facility has safety features on many units to help (1) contain and control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:



Release detection- The following methods are in place to detect various incidents and provide an appropriate signaling mechanism or other remedy to control any effects that may be caused: 

- Chemical detectors with alarms and/or automatic shutdown systems



Release containment and control- The following methods are in place to control any releases:

- Scrubber to neutralize chemical releases

- Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and/or automated)

- Automated shutdown system

s for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

- Vessels to permit partial removal of the process inventory in the event of a release (e.g., a dump tank)

- Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

- Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, backup firewater pump)

- Atmospheric relief devices

- Isobutylene water injection / displacement system



Release mitigation- The following methods are employed to mitigate effects of releases: 

- Fire suppression and extinguishing systems 

- Deluge system for specific equipment

- Trained emergency response personnel

- Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

- Blast-resistant buildings to help protect personnel



Five-year Accident History (68.155(d))



The facility has not experienced any accident in the past 5 years involving an RMP-regulated substance that resulted in any of the EPA-specified onsite or off-site effects.  



Emergency Response Program Information (68.155(e))



The Facility maintains a written emergency response program, in place to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of an Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes or other plant facilities.  



The overall emergency response program for the Facility is coordinated with the St. Clair County Local Emergency Planning Committee, local fire and police departments, and state and federal agencies through the Incident Command System.  The Facility has round-the-clock communications capability with appropriate community officials and emergency response o

rganizations (e.g., the fire department).  The Facility conducts periodic emergency response exercises as well as at least monthly refresher training.   



Planned Changes to Improve Safety (68.155(f))



Afton Chemical Corporation resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which may result in modifications to the process.



The following changes are planned:

-  The site is in the process of implementing a manufacturing production system aimed at standardizing work practices, engaging employees throughout the organization, defining and measuring key performance indicators, and driving efficient and consistent performance. Environmental, health, and safety has been integrated as a key pillar of the production system.  

-  The site recently migrated to a new mechanical integrity management software system and will continue to consolidate maintenance and inspection information into the system, which has allowed for improved tracking of key metrics and better visibility of inspections. Additionally, the asset integrity team is reviewing and updating the piping inspection plans for many of the piping circuits throughout the plant.

-  The site currently utilizes API 754 criteria for identifying and tracking lagging process safety indicators as members of the American Chemistry Council. The site also has an electronic tracking system for leading process safety indicators and challenges to safety systems. This system is planned to be improved to continue to drive process safety performance and reduce process safety events.



In the last 5 years Afton has implemented a behavior-based safety program designed to engage all employees throughout the organization, has maintained its status as members of OSHA's VPP program at STAR level, and upgraded fixed gas monitoring for carbon disulfide and flammable gases in two of our covered processes. Additionally, the plant has implemented a critical safety function management program intended to ensure that interlocks, procedures, a

nd other process controls that are designed to prevent or mitigate a hazard do not significantly deviate from design intent. The program includes scheduled review and maintenance of the process controls and procedures identified as safety critical. The plant also installed several occupied building upgrades based on recommendations from a plant-wide facility siting review.



Finally, Afton continues to reassess its current PSM and RMP practices to look for ways to improve these programs.  This ongoing effort is part of Afton's commitment to compliance and ACC's Responsible Care program.
